articles.headline: With a Hush, an American Lexus Plant Goes to Work
articles.snippet: Starting the new Lexus plant in Georgetown, Ky., meant introducing autoworkers to the brand’s methods, some of which call for a quiet assembly line.
articles.abstract: Starting the new Lexus plant in Georgetown, Ky., meant introducing autoworkers to the brand’s methods, some of which call for a quiet assembly line.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, a switch was flipped at a sprawling auto factory in Georgetown, Ky., and with it, Toyota started building Lexus cars in the United States for the first time.

articles.headline: Volkswagen, Offering Amnesty, Asks Workers to Come Forward on Emissions Cheating
articles.snippet: The company, trying to get to the bottom of its emissions cheating scandal, pressured employees to tell what they know.
articles.abstract: The company, trying to get to the bottom of its emissions cheating scandal, pressured employees to tell what they know.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen, trying to get to the bottom of its emissions-cheating scandal, on Thursday pressured employees to tell what they know, announcing an amnesty program for informants that will expire at the end of the month.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Several Fed Officials Say They Are Ready to Raise Rates
articles.snippet: William C. Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, sees a stronger case for the Federal Open Market Committee to increase rates.
articles.abstract: William C. Dudley, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, sees a stronger case for the Federal Open Market Committee to increase rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials, poised to start raising the central bank’s benchmark interest rate in December, are turning from the question of whether to act to how quickly the Fed should raise rates thereafter.

articles.headline: Huge Valeant Stake Exposes Rift at Sequoia Fund
articles.snippet: Two directors resigned over the Valeant holding at the fund, long a favorite of Warren E. Buffett.
articles.abstract: Two directors resigned over the Valeant holding at the fund, long a favorite of Warren E. Buffett.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than four decades, the Sequoia Fund has been the envy of Wall Street, one of the rare funds to consistently beat the market. Known for its close ties to Warren E. Buffett, the fund at its peak managed more than $9 billion. It was in such demand that it closed to new investors in 2013, a move that enhanced its mystique.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Candidates Target Immigration Policy as Litmus Test in Presidential Race
articles.snippet: The long-distance skirmishing illustrated the degree to which several Republican candidates see immigration as the most potent weapon in the presidential contest.
articles.abstract: The long-distance skirmishing illustrated the degree to which several Republican candidates see immigration as the most potent weapon in the presidential contest.
articles.lead_paragraph: A long-simmering debate over immigration in the Republican presidential contest boiled over on Thursday, as Senator Ted Cruz accused his colleague, Senator Marco Rubio, of “trying to jam this amnesty down the American people’s throats.”
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman and Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: A Global Academy’s Crash Course Makes Angels Out of Investors
articles.snippet: Angel Labs has organized workshops in more than 38 countries for prospective investors who want to learn how to size up entrepreneurs and their ideas.
articles.abstract: Angel Labs has organized workshops in more than 38 countries for prospective investors who want to learn how to size up entrepreneurs and their ideas.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nearly every week, all around the world, wealthy people, self-made business owners and senior executives in a range of industries gather at private clubs, cultural centers or five-star hotels for free, invitation-only angel investing “boot camps” intended to help them size up fledgling business ideas and the people behind them.

articles.headline: At Aeroflot, It’s Patriotism Over Profits as Russia Pressures Industry
articles.snippet: As Russia struggles under sanctions and low oil prices, it is pushing its national airline and others to help support homegrown companies.
articles.abstract: As Russia struggles under sanctions and low oil prices, it is pushing its national airline and others to help support homegrown companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — All smiles and cheery banter, the flight attendants greeted travelers on board Russia’s newest passenger jet.

articles.headline: Finding a Purpose, and Winning a Prize for It
articles.snippet: An annual cash prize recognizes and supports the work of people 60 and older to improve their communities.
articles.abstract: An annual cash prize recognizes and supports the work of people 60 and older to improve their communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jamal Joseph stood helplessly on a Harlem sidewalk. He was outside his apartment building watching a circle of women trying to console the mother of a 16-year-old boy who had been fatally shot.

articles.headline: After Merger, Two Competing Drugs and Billion-Dollar Questions
articles.snippet: A lawsuit claims that a giant French pharmaceutical favored its own multiple sclerosis treatment to avoid making a huge payout.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit claims that a giant French pharmaceutical favored its own multiple sclerosis treatment to avoid making a huge payout.
articles.lead_paragraph: The investing world is riddled with conflicts of interest that can surprise even the most sophisticated investor. Learning that lesson the hard way are holders of an instrument issued in 2011 when Sanofi, the giant French pharmaceutical company, took over Genzyme, a biotech concern based in Cambridge, Mass.
